title: Life Expectancy and Population
text:
This page will explore the relationship between life expectancy and population for all countries in all years in the Gapminder dataset.
gapminder <- read.csv("./gapminder.csv")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Life Expectancy and Population
section: Scatterplot of Life Expectancy and Population
text:
Scatterplot of Life Expectancy and Population

ggplot(data=gapminder, mapping = aes(x=life_expectancy, y=population_millions))+
geom_point(alpha = 0.4)+
labs(title = "Life Expectancy vs. Population", x = "Life Expectancy (years)", y="Population (millions)")








Upon looking at this plot of life expectancy and population, we see that countries with higher life expectancies also seem to also have a higher population on average. However, this relationship isnâ€™t as pronounced compared to life expectancy and GDP, as there are many countries with low GDPs that also have a wide range of life expectancy at the lower y-values.

title: qtm350-summer-quiz02
text:
The Gapminder dataset has data from 1952-2007 for 142 countries on life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population.
This website examines the following 3 relationships:

Life expectancy and GDP per capita
Life expectancy and population
Changes in life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population for the country of Canada over time.

title: qtm350-summer-quiz02
text:
The Gapminder dataset has data from 1952-2007 for 142 countries on life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population.
This website examines the following 3 relationships:

Life expectancy and GDP per capita
Life expectancy and population
Changes in life expectancy, GDP per capita, and population for the country of Canada over time.

title: Country Analysis
text:
This page will explore all 3 metrics of life expectancy, population, and GDP per capita for Canada from 1952-2007.
gapminder <- read.csv("./gapminder.csv")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)
canada <- gapminder[gapminder$country=="Canada",]

title: Country Analysis
section: Canadian GDP per Capita by Year
text:
Canadian GDP per Capita by Year

ggplot(data=canada)+
geom_col(mapping = aes(x=year, y=gdp_per_capita), fill = "green")+
labs(title = "Canadian GDP per Capita from 1952-2007", x = "Year", y="GDP per Capita")

title: Country Analysis
text:
Canadian Population by Year

ggplot(data=canada)+
geom_col(mapping = aes(x=year, y=population_millions), fill = "red")+
labs(title = "Canadian Population from 1952-2007", x = "Year", y="Population (millions)")

title: Country Analysis
text:
Canadian Life Expectancy by Year

ggplot(data=canada)+
geom_col(mapping = aes(x=year, y=life_expectancy), fill = "blue")+
labs(title = "Canadian Life Expectancy from 1952-2007", x = "Year", y="Life Expectancy (years)")








We see that all 3 metrics, GDP per capita, population, and life expectancy, steadily increase throughout 1952-2007. GDP per capita has over tripled and population has over doubled, while life expectancy seems to have increased around 20%.

title: Create the Gapminder dataset
text:
# Import necessary libraries
import pandas as pd
from gapminder import gapminder

# Rename 'lifeExp' to 'life_expectancy' and 'gdpPercap' to 'gdp_per_capita'
gapminder = gapminder.rename(columns={'lifeExp': 'life_expectancy',
                                      'pop': 'population_millions', 
                                      'gdpPercap': 'gdp_per_capita'})

# Convert population to millions
gapminder['population_millions'] = gapminder['population_millions'] / 1_000_000

# Create a new pandas DataFrame from the modified gapminder data
gapminder_df = pd.DataFrame(gapminder)

# Save the DataFrame as a CSV file
gapminder_df.to_csv('gapminder.csv', index=False)

# Print the first 3 rows of the DataFrame
print(gapminder_df.head(3))

       country continent  year  life_expectancy  population_millions  \
0  Afghanistan      Asia  1952           28.801             8.425333   
1  Afghanistan      Asia  1957           30.332             9.240934   
2  Afghanistan      Asia  1962           31.997            10.267083   

   gdp_per_capita  
0      779.445314  
1      820.853030  
2      853.100710

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text:
This page will explore the relationship between life expectancy and GDP per capita for all countries in all years in the Gapminder dataset.
gapminder <- read.csv("./gapminder.csv")
pacman::p_load(tidyverse)

title: Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
section: Scatterplot of Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita
text:
Scatterplot of Life Expectancy and GDP per Capita

ggplot(data=gapminder, mapping = aes(x=life_expectancy, y=gdp_per_capita))+
geom_point(alpha = 0.4)+
labs(title = "Life Expectancy vs. GDP per Capita", x = "Life Expectancy (years)", y="GDP per Capita")








Upon looking at this plot of life expectancy and GDP per capita, we see that countries with higher life expectancies also tend to have a higher GDP per capita on average.
